name: Virginia
description: Virginia is a single-player first-person thriller set in a small town with a secret. Experience a missing person investigation through the eyes of graduate FBI agent Anne Tarver.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 and higher, 32-bit or 64 bit Processor: AMD Phenom II X4 940 or Intel Pentium G4400 Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Radeon R7 250 or GeForce GTX 650, 1GB VRAM DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 5 GB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 10 64-bit Processor: AMD FX-6300 or Intel Core 15-2300 Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Radeon HD 7870 or GTX 660, 2GB VRAM DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 5 GB available space

reviews.review_text: When a game is as beautiful and full of potential as Virginia is, it's difficult to admit that its flaws outweigh its better aspects. I wanted to like this game, but I feel like I'd be lying if I were to recommend it.   The art and music work well together to fashion a stunning world from an aesthetic standpoint, but upon closer inspection that world falls apart. The lack of interactivity in the environments are more reminiscent than a sparse model home than the life-filled spaces of Gone Home or Firewatch. Unfortunately, it doesn't have the same charm of other 'walking simulators' to carry it. The game's soundtrack is ambitious, but inadequately implemented (more on this in a moment). The game's scenes are jarringly short, which ends up as a bit of a paradox, as the game's pacing makes it feel like one long scene rather than a fulfilling narrative. At the length of a fairly short movie by today's standards, Virginia still dragged. The soundtrack tries to match the game's pacing, and succeeds for some of the quieter moments, but the tense scenes feel too thinly stretched, going on for far too long for the music's urgency to have the same impact.   From a gameplay standpoint, there isn't exactly much to talk about. Your control over the main character is criminally shallow, leaving a unsatisfying disconnect. Often in environments there's only one thing to interact with, and there's no feeling of exploration when you're being railroaded through the story with even less agency than similar titles. It's difficult to call Virginia a 'walking simulator' when you aren't even doing much of that, but 'clicking simulator' sounds too close to point-and-click adventures, so I suppose I must settle for 'watching simulator.' This brings an issue to mind: I'd much rather be watching this story as a movie than playing it as a game, especially given how little gameplay there actually is. Were this an animated film, perhaps it would have faired better, but as a game--even as a narrative experience--it's sorely lacking in giving any sense of fulfillment.   Much of the unfulfilled feeling this game leaves lies in the story. Now, I'm not dead set on narratives requiring traditional structures, and I love movies that incorporate strong visual storytelling (Upstream Color comes to mind), but Virginia's narrative has an indirectness that leads to confusion rather than good old fashioned min♥♥♥♥ery. The developers did, indeed, set out to make a confusing game, but rather than being a complex mystery Virginia ends up as a scattered, unfocused, vague mess. Trust me, I got the major points of the story. It isn't that hard to piece together. However, what the game presents is, again, unsatisfying. I believe a lot of this is due to the lack of voice acting. While the NPCs were characterized well, Anne herself feels criminally shallow for the weight attributed to her story. The player doesn't identify with her because her motivation's don't align with ours in the slightest. Were there some narration, perhaps this wouldn't have been so jarring, but as it stands this alienation doesn't add anything to the game.   I feel like this game could have been more. Had the player been given more agency, there would have been a better connection to the story rather than the unshakable feeling of being an outsider. The visual style doesn't make up for the lifeless environments, and the music is largely hit or miss, with more of the latter in the long run. The story felt rushed and the pacing dragged, and the game's world isn't fleshed out enough to feel its own.  To sum it up in a word, Virginia was unsatisfying. Perhaps I'm missing the point. But perhaps the game just needs to make its point better.

Stay away from this game.  Game design: Get thrown around scenes, walk a bit, collect collectibles, get thrown around scenes. These scenes together form a story.  The game, in its design, works pretty well for me. At least the first half of the game. Then it just goes ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and I had to force myself to finish it.  You don't even end up with lots of questions... there's only one question: what the ♥♥♥♥ were they thinking?

The artwork is great, but the lack of any voice overs or dialogue leaves a lot to be desired. Also, sometimes you'll be walking and you'll suddenly be transported to a new area without warning or even a fade out/in scene transition, which is disorienting. Using an Xbox 360 wired controller, there is still lag time between hitting a button and a reaction in the game, particularly when looking into mirrors. And why there is not controller-specific y-axis inversion I'll never understand. Finally, since the game is designed to take you through a story, there isn't much else to do except press A when prompted by the indicator.

Jesus ♥♥♥♥ing Christ I'm dizzy! I really wanted to like this game, the trailers made it look like it had an interesting story, but like many others I felt dizzy and sick after just a few minutes. The game recommends that you play on 30 fps which I get because the developer wanted a more cinematic feel to the game. The game allows you to push the frame rate to 60, or even unlocked but that doesn't solve the problem. The developer severely limited the graphic options for this game and as a result force us to deal with nauseating motion blur! on top of that there is no FOV slider, so you are forced to play through the game with a cramped FOV. I cannot suggest this game to anyone. Do yourself a favor and save your money.

A lot of the negative reviews come from the same issue: There is no gameplay. And they're right, this is a textbook Walking Simulator. I think Virginia was a beautifully well told story but that's all it is. No puzzles, no dialogue options, no dialogue at all.  I personally love this genre. People have been asking why isn't this just a movie, if the player has zero input other than movement? But the appeal of these Walking Sims are that YOU are the main character. It's much easier to empathize and get invested in her story, because it's happening to YOU. Not some character on screen. And the lack of dialogue lets you implant your own conversations and reactions and thoughts from your character. That really get you inside her head.  The downside of the presentation, is that a few story elements were lost on me. Things I didn't realize or understand until reading up on it, but that's obviously going to vary per person. There's a lot of Lynch inspired surrealism here that's meant to be left to the player.  Final Thoughts: This was a great, beautiful little story. One that I'm very glad I bought. But it's 100% dependent on story. The fact that they're even able to tell such a understandable story without a single line of dialouge is hugely impressive
A very linear mystery game/playable movie with super awesome soundtrack.

There is no game. There is a strange 2 hours long silent movie with short stories about life. Quite good one with awesome original soundtrack.  Play, oh i mean watch the demo version and/or 'Thirty Flights of Loving' before purchase.

While we now live in a gaming world where every 2 months five new narrated story games are released in which you only have to either walk forward and press a mouse button or watch and press the right button at the right time - this one is the one you should get anyways. Even if you are annoyed by everything coming your way. This game is different. It doesnt overstay its welcome, although the ending is a bit stretched out, the graphic style is something you will have to like - I did tho. And this is my review, so I can do what I want and I want to recommend it. Pick it up at sale like I did tho, 10 bucks for 2 hours is a little too much.

Based on the 'influences' of what's in the description and the praise it got on gaming websites, I dove into this expecting a great story....and I didn't get that. I hate not recommending something but I didn't find my time valued here.
Didn't make a lot sense to me, I feel like it's a bit misleading to call this a mystery game.

A wonderful narrative journey through the what ifs, what are, and could be's of the decisions you make in fareful moments of your life. It's best to say you'll either love this game or hate it, but I'd say if you want to enjoy it to its fullest give the game your full attention, the amazing score and great cinematography really propel this game above what could be just a ok story.  Turn off your second monitor, turn the speakers up, and let the experience engross you.

If there was ever a game to be labeled as an 'experience', Virginia is the one. Note how I didnt say 'interactive experience'.  Virginia is a game, however the creators have used the game medium to tell the story they wished to tell and they have done that marvelously. The enviroments are well designed and play off the art style while the pacing is clearly inspired by the works they credit.  In terms of a game there is little to do. You progress through scenes by interacting (moving the analogue stick and pressing A/X is the entirety of your input potential) with key elements. Going into Virigina it being a first person story driven game I expected a few gamified elements, and to satisfy these cravings there are collectable feathers and flowers. However, these only add a subtle cosmetic touch to some scenes and outside of the game they yeild nothing.  This is more a fact that an opinion. Virginia may be a game, but is one that makes use of the interaction by letting you move through the story, It knows it. It does it well, and you will finish the game with plenty of your own thoughts and ideas bubbling away.  It's and experience more than a game, and that isn't always a bad thing.  A good cup of coffee/10

I've seen meaningless arthouse games before. They said this was different.   It was.  Despite having far more money and the Prague orchestra than other indie games this manages to be the most incoherant and pretentious 'game' I've seen: it uses exclusivley the W key and the left mouse button.   Self indulgent ambiguity is not depth, and a nice score and artwork isn't a game.   And no, I'm not playing the game another time; that racket was only an interesting idea in Undertale and it hasn't gotten any better.

Seemed very cool at first, since I really liked Twin Peaks, and Fargo and it really was very alike, but there is no interaction what some ever. At first I really liked it since it also gave off a bit of a Firewatch felling, with it's mystery. But in Firewatch you can interact with your surrounding, and with Deliala but you cannot do anything else but open the door that you have to and do EXCATLY what you have to. You CANNOT do ANYTHING but continue playing, no looking at things, interacting with items, or anything else. This game isk basically a movie that continues at your own pace.

I seriously love this game. And I further love it for paying homage to the clear inspiration - Brendan Cheung's 'Thirty Flights of Loving'.  The soundtrack is beautiful, and the game is very David Lynch-ian. The cut-jumps are a bit clunky in places, and finding feathers is a little tiresome minigame amongst a narrative-led experience, but overall it's superbly produced and highly artistic.
Different than usual. You will be confused.
Beautiful and intelligent, like watching a David Lynch movie.
Firewatch, INSIDE, That Dragon, Cancer with a symphony to back it.  An experience moreso than a game, 100 thumbs up if I had that many.

Not what I was expecting, don't listen to people calling it 'art' or 'experimental' it's a lazy, short, boring, non-interactive 'game' that was THE most dissapointing 'game' to come out in years.   I got the story, I understood the meanings behind it. But it is NOT a great 'game'. This would have been better as a film.   You best watch it on youtube, you are not missing out on anything apart from collecting feathers and flowers.   It needed more interactivity, more substance and less of this 'minimalist gameplay'  3/10  Wish I could get a refund as i wanted a 'game' not a movie!

First off, there is a lie in the games description 'you will make decisions which irrevocably shape the course of Anne’s and agent Halperin’s lives.' - That is totally untrue, the player makes ZERO decisions in this game. I don't even care that it's a walking simulator, but this misleads you to think otherwise.  It was nothing like Twin Peaks or X-Files, as advertised.  Nice graphics and fantastic soundtrack don't save this walking simulators silly, artsy-fartsy story that makes little to no sense towards the end.  I tried to understand the 'conclusion' of this game, but it falls into confusing cliche stereotypes of this kind of genre and overloads you with a bunch of literal nonsense. It felt like it was trying to be weird for the sake of it. Disappointed, as it had great potential.  FOV is really low too, no options to fix. Also, for some weird reason it tells you that 60fps mode is not the way it should be played, which made me worry that something was going to break, but it hardly elaborates on why it tries to guide you into a 30fps lock.  I feel misled and let down.

What did I just play? Really? I'm not sure I understand what was trying to be communicated.  I don't think it's bad. I guess I think people who like story over game are going to be happy (I do) but perhaps some key information is not accessible during the game. I often felt like I had no idea what was going on.  Maybe that was the point.

Before I played Virginia, I wasn't really sure what to do with my evening. I wanted to watch something, to passively consume, but couldn't find a movie that would hold my fleeting attention. I considered picking up a controller and trying to engross myself in a game, but nothing took my fancy. Then I saw Virginia in my library, unplayed, and thought I'd see whether that would scratch both itches.  Long story short, it really did.  Takes as purely a game, it falls several hundred feet short of being noteworthy. There is no real gameplay of which to speak; if you're in a corridor, for example, there are no doors you can open just to see inside, no boxes you can check for clues or collectibles. You can walk around occasionally, but it's mostly just 'Press A to Continue'  As a story, it has some flaws too. I don't think the writers wanted to create a game like The Wolf Among Us, or anything similar. Rather, this is much more of an indie arthouse-style film, with liberal use of cinematography and tropes like the feared 'dream-sequence' to cast doubt on the factual events, even as the credits roll.   Why then did I enjoy it so much? Because despite all of these problems, it still delivered a beautiful-looking, novel and engrossing experience, with an interesting first and second act, and a score so cinematic you can't help but engage. Furthermore, the above-mentioned narrative choices leave a lasting impression, with doubts and questions about the outcome of the plot swirling. To my mind, that only adds to the enjoyment.  It's £7. Sit with a friend or a partner, and play this for the 1-2 hours it takes, rather than staring at Netflix (again). I guarantee, you'll want to talk about it after.

I made the mistake of believing the 'Incredibly deep story!' reviews. 'Virginia' tries way too hard to pay homage to David Lynch and forgets that funky visual metaphors aren't enough... engaging characters, an interesting plot, and effective pacing are what gives the funkiness punch. There's nothing 'deep' about this story unless you choose to infer a novel's worth of unjustified conjecture from psychoanalyzing the clichéd dream sequences.  Beyond the story, the 'interactive' portions of the narrative are merely annoyances and do nothing to engage the player or serve as dramatic edits/cuts. Maybe this could be effective as a VR movie experience that avoids 'gameplay' all together... but the story is so thin, emotion is so lacking, and the metaphors are so heavy handed that I doubt even VR could distract you long enough.  I’ll wrap up by saying that I might have enjoyed 'Virginia' more if I hadn't just been kicked in the gut by 'Firewatch’s' all emotion, minimal story approach... but probably not. Then again, my “Firewatch” love will probably be enough to disqualify my opinion for some. :P

Short review: Virginia is awful, truly awful.  Long review: Virginia is the newest in a long line of so-called 'walking simulators' - games that barely qualify as such. I'm going to assume that the reader is familiar with this emergent form of gameplay so that I can cut to the chase. Virginia does not make a single attempt to justify its choice of medium. Interaction is completely linear - the concept of choice does not exist. Other walking simulators, to use the infamous Gone Home as an example, often have supplementary material littered throughout the game to help flesh out the world and immerse the player. The player can either rush through the game, or take things slowly and examine their environment. Corridors in Virginia are completely empty, and thus all the player can do is walk from point A to point B (is this the truest form of walking simulator?). Without any interaction or exploration possible, there is no reason for Virginia to be a video game. I'll take it a step farther, it actively tries NOT to be a video game at times, completely preventing the player from moving the camera or heavily restricting its use.  If Virginia's not a game, we'll have to look at it as a film. Virginia never gives the viewer a reason to care about its characters or what is happening on-screen, but expects them to anyway. At one point the protagonist is flipping through archived documents and really exciting music is playing and it really feels like this is supposed to be some incredible earth-shattering revelation but it all feels so empty and that's just the way the whole thing feels. The lack of dialogue simply does not work in a setting like this, and it prevents any meaningful characterization from happening. It almost seems like this decision was an afterthought after the devs were unable to find any decent voice actors, but this is just speculation on my part. The empty rooms and silence by the characters create a powerful one-two punch of apathy in the viewer, and turn what should have been a relatively straightforward plot into one that can be hard to decipher at times.  The plot in Virginia is nothing special and in the end doesn't really have anything new or important to say. This isn't to say that every film needs to have some sort of message, but I cannot think of a single unifying theme present throughout Virginia. It's simply a series of events that happen without purpose, and purpose is the key word here because Virginia does not have one and no matter how long I think I cannot justify its existence. I cannot see the Twin Peaks comparison outside of the character that looks suspiciously like Agent Cooper - (at least the first part of) the series had a clear purpose, and the characters themselves were charming enough to care about. I cannot see this as a character study akin to Mulholland Drive - again, it's just so empty and the lack of dialogue does not work at all (maybe this is just a way of saying that the protagonist is mentally handicapped).  Technically, too, Virginia is a mess. This is of course subjective, but the art style is extremely ugly in its strange blockiness and simplistic lighting. Less subjective is how mechanical a lot of the movements appear - a character will suddenly start moving a hand without any sort of build-up, and sometimes they'll completely stop moving at all. Having such unrealistic movement in a work that already doesn't feel very immersive only further detracts from the experience.  As game or film, Virginia fails on all fronts. Whatever you do, do not buy this game, even ironically. If you are looking for a 'so bad it's good' experience I can point you to several similar games (personally out of 2016's releases I've enjoyed That Dragon, Cancer) that you and your friends may find entertaining. Games have the potential to hold serious artistic merit, but those like Virginia make no effort to carve out their own path, instead opting to take the lazy way out and attempting to copy film. The more I write about this game the more I hate it, and I hope that everyone involved in its creation got a good spanking when it was all over.  Taster’s score: C-

I enjoyed it very much.  And here is why:  first of all - you have no speach of characters Only environemtal sounds and very great orchestral music. Animations are clean and i like the style of art in here.  Regarding that this game is made by a few people only, it has a good quality in telling you a weird story. This story has some interesting moments and emotionals aswell.  You will have to be patient in some moments and must be open for a very story-driven game. Otherwise, you won't have much fun.  There only a few long movement parts in game, where you follow a certain route. All in all, the game is very much linear, no left or right.   I would say its a good deal for a special movie-game. Your playtime will be about 2h, which is suitable for a movie - but maybe to short for a game (?)  Try it!  7.5/10 points
Hey - I love walking simulators. This is .... just basically acid simulator. 2 hours of gameplay for nothing super evocative except a good score.

This game fits into a small niche that definitely won't appeal to everyone. It has an intriguing story that leaves room for multiple interpretations. Whether or not this is even a 'game' or an interactive movie is also up for debate. I do wonder if parts of the story were obscure just for the sake of it, or whether the writers have a deliberate message. Either way, it gets a thumbs up for its interesting narrative style.

Well worth your money and a few hours of your time. This is a more streamlined experience than similar games like Firewatch and Gone Home, which means it plays more like an interactive film than a game. Don't expect to busy yourself searching the environments for newspapers, books, letters, or other found documents that would deepen your immersion in the game world. Instead, sit back and let the game guide you through a very curated and fascinating two hours. Some may find the ending inscrutable, but I think it wraps up nicely while still providing you plenty to think about and chew over.

I have MSc in Game Design, I know what a game is and what is not.  I will be honest with you: This is not a game, go watch any YouTube 'let's play' and save your money.   This is an interactive movie where you only have to use keyboard, mouse or gamepad to look for the next object to trigger the next scene.  All the good things about this 'game 'are cinema related (camera, edition...) Thar really explains how little amount of gameplay it has, if any at all.  Is it a good movie? Kind of, if you like David lynch, Donnie darko....but not an excellent one.  Unfortunately there are too many hipsters infiltrated in the games industry, making games is trendy now...

First of all let me say that I am biased to anything with good music, and the orchestral language utilized by Virginia is nothing short of spectacular. The sheer breadth of the music is astonishing, it moves smoothly from touching to curious, to excitement, to shock… In fact, it is what I find to be the central piece in navigating through the somewhat chaotic narrative structure. It holds the central theme of each segment and paves the way for the movement ahead. For me, the music brought alive the story, especially when there is no speech to be found, it fills the void with something truly sublime.  Virginia is a courageous experiment, it is heavy-handed and linear, but compact and elegant. This is my personal preference, but I found a remarkable sensitivity from the creators of this game. Given the fractured structure and many surprising narrative jumps, I found myself swaying on the thin line between maddening frustration and curiosity. It somehow managed provide a solid footing while constantly knocking you off balance. Aside from the array of 1990s TV references, the skill and attention needed in crafting this story demands my applause.  It is very difficult to speak to the pros and cons for this game, if you can call it one. It is a mosaic of moving pieces, only to be vaguely made-out from afar. This is an entirely different animal. It is also the product of many rather interesting choices, for one, why make a video game if there is pretty much no interactivity? Really, what is the point of a game if you can get just as much out of it by watching someone else play? Player freedom seems to have been redirected to pointless movements such as looking at trees and flowers and bird feathers. Yet it provided a strange level of depth to this intricately crafted story, but maybe it is just my post hoc justification. No, I don't think they are commenting on the metaphysics of choice and folly of free-will. It seemed to me to be fundamentally artistic, meant for expression under the suspension of disbelief, not persuasion, and most definitely not meant for entertainment. My struggle with this work is that I found no catharsis or insight at the end, I really thought it was coming. To be frank, it made no sense to me. Its significance wholly capsulated in its own world, safely removed from the player. The compound of overlapping motifs and symbolisms was not granted the time nor the space to fuse and yield meaning. It is as if they piled up a bunch of fireworks for the finale, but just as it’s about to go off, instead you are handed a piece of paper which reads, “oh, and then the fireworks went off.” Bloody infuriating.  The immediate experience of Virginia is incomplete, the whole thing has the feel of a phenomenological experiment for a post-modern art study. But despite its faults, I found myself very much enjoying the artistry, the craftsmanship, and above all, the masterful music of Virginia. One last point, I feel this game deserves to be put into VR, it would mitigate much of the interactivity issue.
Very good, but beatable in 2 hours.

So there's no dialog between characters- very frustrating. The pictures/ art was good. Also disappointing as you're not really solving a 'myster'- you just follow along- no choice to decide anything.  They could do a lot of improvement- plus allow people to click on certain areas of map and go.
